channel.title: Tidyverse on Tarana-Fundamentals of Data Analystics
channel.description: Recent content in Tidyverse on Tarana-Fundamentals of Data Analystics

item.title: Final Project: Business Analysis
item.description: Assessing the financial benefit of the project This project would benefit credit card providers by detecting customers who have the potential of missing their credit card payments. Although this is not an unfamiliar situation for these institutions, it affects their revenue every year by making them prosecute these clients. This project gives you two options two avoid these customers based on two categories of information you already have!

item.title: Final Project: Business Analytics
item.description: Assessing the financial benefit of the project This project would benefit credit card providers by detecting customers who have the potential of missing their credit card payments. Although this is not an unfamiliar situation for these institutions, it affects their revenue every year by making them prosecute these clients. This project gives you two options two avoid these customers based on two categories of information you already have!

item.title: Tree based Method: Random Forest
item.description: Overview To implement Random Forest method, the bank data set is used here, on which dataset, the classification technique is used earlier. As we know, Random Forest being one of the supervised machine learning, provides more flexibility and accuracy of the model over decision trees adding extra randomness. In Random Forests the idea is to decorrelate the several trees which are generated by the different bootstrapped samples from training Data.

item.title: Classification models : Logistic Regression
item.description: Summary of Data The data is related with direct marketing campaigns of a Portuguese banking institution. The marketing campaigns were based on phone calls. To identify whether a customer would subscribe the bank term deposit or not, most of the time more than one contact to the same customer was required. Now,the information of a customers age, job, marital, education, default, balance, housing, loan, contact along side the data of day, month, duration, campaign, previous days, previous, previous outcome are available.

item.title: Regression Models
item.description: Dataset at a glance: A Professor of machine learning, when planned to buy diamond ring for engagement, came to know that the pricing diamonds is not so easy.As a consequence of that, he collects data from three different wholesalers on 440 different diamonds. Now he has information on prices of these diamonds along with their characteristic features such as color, clarity, cut and carat (famous 4Cs) besides polish, symmetry and certification.

item.title: Final Project
item.description: Data Analysis to fit Linear Regression Model: This is an exploratory data analysis report to fit the simple Linear Regression Model. This report concerns a dataset about Life Expectancy. Categorical and numerical explanatory variables analysis: For finding whether there is any relation between the dataset or not, I have done some basic analysis to find the dependent and independent variables.From these analysis, the variable, Life Expectancy has came out as dependent variable(y) as it is effected by other predictive variables.

item.title: A05: EDA2
item.description: Exploratory Data Analysis: This is my second exploratory analysis report for the course of Fundamentals of Business Analysis. This report concerns a dataset about Crimes report from 2001 of a city of USA. Here, I have performed some very basic analysis with the dataset. Dataset: Crimes-2001 to present data (Chicago City) This dataset is about reported incidents of crime (with the exception of murders where data exists for each victim) that occurred in the City of Chicago from 2001 to the most recent days.

item.title: Total funded expense actuals by agency name
item.description: Funded expense actuals by agency name from non-federal dataset of USA The small and simple interactive visualization represents the top five agency name those are funded by the actual expenses according to year 2015, 2016 & 2017. <iframe src=“https://taranaislam.shinyapps.io/mydataworld/”, height = “800” width = “100%” frameborder = “no”>

item.title: Data Import Assignment
item.description: Import Nobel.csv file library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.1 ── ## ✓ ggplot2 3.3.3 ✓ purrr 0.3.4 ## ✓ tibble 3.1.2 ✓ dplyr 1.0.6 ## ✓ tidyr 1.1.3 ✓ stringr 1.4.0 ## ✓ readr 1.4.0 ✓ forcats 0.5.1 ## ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## x dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() nobel <- read_csv(file = "nobel.csv") ## ## ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── ## cols( ## .

item.title: Data Recode Assignment
item.description: Import and Transform Religion-income.csv library(readxl) library(dplyr) ## ## Attaching package: 'dplyr' ## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': ## ## filter, lag ## The following objects are masked from 'package:base': ## ## intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(tidyr) library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.1 ── ## ✓ ggplot2 3.3.3 ✓ purrr 0.3.4 ## ✓ tibble 3.1.2 ✓ stringr 1.4.0 ## ✓ readr 1.4.0 ✓ forcats 0.5.1 ## ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## x dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() rel_inc <- read_excel("relig-income.

item.title: Assignment A02: TIDYVERSE
item.description: For using one table verb functions,I have chosen heart failure clinical records dataset. Heart failure is a common event caused by CVDs and this dataset contains 12 features that can be used to predict mortality by heart failure. I have applied two functions only here. library(tidyverse) heartdisease <- read_csv("heart_failure_clinical_records_dataset.csv") #head(heart_failure_clinical_records_dataset) head(heartdisease) ## # A tibble: 6 x 13 ## age anaemia creatinine_phosphok… diabetes ejection_fracti… high_blood_press… ## <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 75 0 582 0 20 1 ## 2 55 0 7861 0 38 0 ## 3 65 0 146 0 20 0 ## 4 50 1 111 0 20 0 ## 5 65 1 160 1 20 0 ## 6 90 1 47 0 40 1 ## # … with 7 more variables: platelets <dbl>, serum_creatinine <dbl>, ## # serum_sodium <dbl>, sex <dbl>, smoking <dbl>, time <dbl>, DEATH_EVENT <dbl> One table verb functions heartdisease %>% filter(diabetes == 1, age >= 50) %>% arrange(desc(serum_creatinine)) %>% select(diabetes, age, serum_creatinine) ## # A tibble: 104 x 3 ## diabetes age serum_creatinine ## <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 1 60 6.

item.title: Data Wrangling using Tidyverse
item.description: Imports the Hotels .csv file library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.1 ── ## ✓ ggplot2 3.3.3 ✓ purrr 0.3.4 ## ✓ tibble 3.1.2 ✓ dplyr 1.0.6 ## ✓ tidyr 1.1.3 ✓ stringr 1.4.0 ## ✓ readr 1.4.0 ✓ forcats 0.5.1 ## ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## x dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() hotels <- read_csv("hotels.csv") ## ## ── Column specification ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── ## cols( ## .
